title: Do police officers get drafted? - Quora

response.answer_text: Uh, no. The US hasn’t drafted anyone since the 1970s. So, if no one gets drafted, obviously, no officers will be drafted. Now, back when we had the draft, or conscription, there was time when you could be drafted. But, there was a problem. If you drafted people who had vital skills to serve, you left openings that had to be filled. This means it took time to train them as well as find people who could do the jobs. OK, this was fine for women working in factories, but for police, fire and rescue, this was bad. To prevent this, certain people were ruled exempt from the draft. How do you think Trump avoided going to Vietnam? He stayed in college, chasing girls and worrying about getting STDS. Oh, and he had bone spurs that mysteriously cleared up. SO, he was 4F, or at least 2F, while he was F-ing around. I want to say, at the time of the draft, that those who couldn’t pass the exam could become police officers or fill in other professions. Kind of a second chance thing for not being fit enough to get killed. But, I know several men and women who have enlisted even though they were immune to the draft, should it start again, and didn’t have to enlist anyway. Some people feel so strongly that they will risk their lives even when they don’t have to. I may not agree with the reasons for the war, but my hat is off to every man and women who has the guts to serve and I’ll damn well die backing them up, no matter what.

Even though all males over 18 register with selective service there are things called critical jobs. Short explanation. In WWII Britain did a full draft to get ready to support France after they declared war. They took all men regardless of their job. A month later most factories and critical services were nearly shut down because the Police, Fire, miners, the only guy who knew how to fix the press at the arms factory etc etc were all in Boot Camp. They were quickly recalled from service and lists of critical occupations were drawn up. Also if you had a job that wasn’t on the list but you were critical to any given company they could get you a waiver from draft. We here in the USA instituted the same policy in our last draft ..Vietnam. I think that last one ended in 73. Anyway we expanded it to include kids in College and a few other areas. This on a side note had the effect of making sure that only the poor or people that couldn’t get into school due to grades or cash went to Vietnam (unless they volunteered). My own father flunked out of Grand Valley State College..knew he would be drafted and joined the Marines so he could at least pick his branch. I guess they straightened him out cause he became a PhD. Imagine how seriously you would study if you knew getting an F meant you were going to be a rifleman in Vietnam 18 week later…lol. So..no. Police, Fire, Teachers and many other professions cant be drafted as those are exempted fields.

The answers of NO are factually incorrect. Only positions deemed critical to national security are exempt. NSA,CIA NOAA, Coast Guard, all federal law enforcement. That's federal law enforcement. Not local or state. There's only one state or local job that would keep you from the draft, and that's an elected official. The US government doesn't care about your city. Fireman, teachers, doctor's etc have been drafted and aren't exempt. Conscientious objectors Ministry Elected political people College student Hardship ( people depend on person) And a few more Everybody is classified as 1A and needs to get status changed if there's an issue Police officers can absolutely 100% be drafted

Some countries have drafts that can include the police. I worked with the Brazilian Military Police for sometime and while they do not accept straight draftees, some of their officers entered the military under Lei do Serviço Militar. And while some people may argue that the Gendarme is different, France filled the ranks of the Gendarme with conscripts for much of its existence to the end of conscription. In the United States the Posse comitatus acts prevents drafting of police forces. The draft in its current and former creations was a tool to enlist military soldiers. By definition, the military cannot enforce laws. That is why FBI agents are attached to military units overseas, and why many military law enforcement branches cannot use agents who hold regular commissions.

Back in the time when Italy had the military draft (until 2005) the contrary could happen, because youngsters called to do their physical exam before being drafted were given the opportunity to serve either in the Police or the “Carabinieri” as “auxiliary police officers”, meaning that - instead of being given a badly fitting uniform and being shipped off to 3 months of basic training followed by 9 months of boredom in some godforsaken barracks in places either too cold or too hot, or for those particularly lucky to be selected to serve in the Navy being literally shipped somewhere for 18 months instead of 12 - be given the opportunity to train in a police academy, get better looking uniforms and definitely better pay, and at the end of the mandatory 12 months having the option of staying for an extra year and, after some extra training, becoming a regular police officer with full pay and career advancement opportunities. Every year at least 2,000 to 3,000 draftees chose to serve as law enforcement officers, and quite a few of them rose to the top ranks.

They did when the US still had the draft. I registered in November 1968. I started with the Sheriff’s department in February 1969 as a cadet and knew at least three deputies who were drafted. There was a deferment for being in college so I claimed it. They took that away, but I got married and claimed that deferment in 1969. They took that away but I had a child so I claimed that one, which they then took away all deferments and instituted the draft lottery. The first drawing draft lottery was December 1969 for the year 1970. Luckily my number came up 174 so I wasn’t in danger of getting called up.

One that I worked with did. In the 1960s, he was a rookie police officer who was called up for the draft during the Vietnam War. I would have thought he could get a deferment, but he either couldn’t or didn’t seek one. He spent two years in the Army, then returned to the police department and resumed his career.

Do you mean get drafted into the Army? Or are you asking if people can be drafted into becoming police officers? The answer to the first question is usually, though there are some circumstances (high need area) that might allow them to stay out. The answer to the second question is that in some Native American tribes, men are expected to take their turn at being peace officers. When the tribal leaders select them, they do their civic duty as a sworn officer. At the end of their term, they go back to ‘real life’.

No, because being a police officer is not like being a soldier. A police officer is there to maintain the law, investigate offences, prevent crime, liaise with the community, provide first responder duties, seize evidence. They usually work fairly autonomously, not in squads or units. If someone has been drafted into this then I highly doubt they would be very effective unless they had desired that career anyway, in which case they would have just joined normally. I suppose if you were to consider an emergency service that could impose the draft then it might be the fire service, but that is a bit maybe.

There has been no draft into military service since 1973. A few years before that, in 1969, they started a lottery system. When that lottery started no one was exempt from the draft because of employment. Before then teachers, police, firefighters and medical doctors were not drafted Police and all others register for the draft but no one has been drafted

Prior to the draft lottery of 1972 full time police who were not still on probation and elementary/HS teachers were exempt from the draft. One of the reasons we had so many males all of a sudden going to college to become teachers in the 1960’s . For 4 years full time college students were also exempt from the draft. When the lottery happened everyone, no matter what the job except a few national security personnel, everyone 18 to 24 with a number of 95 or lower got drafted. After 1972 the draftees number went up since the pool was now much lower being only 18 years olds

You do know we don’t have a draft right now, right? Yes, police officers register for Selective Service when they are 18 (which would be long before they became police officers), but since there is no draft, that’s just trivia for now.
Do you mean drafted into law enforcement? No, we volunteer. The last time police officers were drafted into the military was probably World War 2.
It’s highly unlikely. The country would have be losing hard before it would get desperate enough to draft personnel who already have a public security function.
Your question should be DID police officers get drafted- since there has not been a draft in the US since the 1970s. Before that- yes, they did.
In the US, they do not.
